name: Yosemite National Park
description: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra. First protected in 1864, Yosemite National Park is best known for its waterfalls, but within its nearly 1,200 square miles, you can find deep valleys, grand meadows, ancient giant sequoias, a vast wilderness area, and much more.
shortDescription: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, the persistence of life, and the tranquility of the High Sierra. First protected in 1864, Yose...

operatingHours.description: Yosemite National Park is open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year.

fees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle
fees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days for a non-commercial car, pickup truck, RV, or van with 15 or fewer passenger seats. This fee covers the vehicle and everyone inside of it.

fees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle
fees.description: Valid for 7 days. Admits up to 2 private, non-commercial motorcycles with up to 4 total passengers.

fees.title: Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days for people entering on foot, a bicycle, a horse, or a non-commercial bus or van. People 15 years and younger are free.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan
fees.description: The fee is $20 per person for any resident 16 years or older. For any nonresident the fee is $100 per person for anyone 16 years or older. This fee is valid for seven consecutive days.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van
fees.description: The fee is $20 per person for any resident 16 years or older. For any nonresident the fee is $100 per person for anyone 16 years or older. This fee is valid for seven consecutive days.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus
fees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. For any nonresident there is an additional fee of $100 per person for anyone 16 years or older.  A commercial use authorization is required.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach
fees.description: This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. For any nonresident there is an additional fee of $100 per person for anyone 16 years or older.  A commercial use authorization is required.

fees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups
fees.description: The per-person fee is $20 to a maximum of $300 per vehicle. People 15 years and younger are free.

fees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups
fees.description: An educational fee waiver is available for educational and scientific groups that are accredited or tax-exempt for educational purposes planning a trip for educational or scientific purposes related to Yosemite that is not primarily recreational.

fees.title: Commercial Entrance - Per Person
fees.description: The fee is $25 plus $20 per person, not to exceed $105. This fee is valid for seven consecutive days. A commercial use authorization is required.

fees.title: Nonresident
fees.description: Each non-US resident aged 16 and older visiting Yosemite National Park must pay a $100 nonresident fee (in addition to the standard entrance fee), unless admitted with an Annual or America the Beautiful Pass. This includes nonresidents entering as part of a commercial tour group, commercial use authorization (CUA) group, or concessioner tour group.

climate.weatherDescription: Yosemite National Park covers nearly 1,200 square miles (3,100 square km) in the Sierra Nevada, with elevations ranging from about 2,000 feet (600 m) to 13,000 ft (4,000 m). Yosemite receives 95% of its precipitation between October and May (and over 75% between November and March). Most of Yosemite is blanketed in snow from about November through May. (Yosemite Valley can be rainy or snowy in any given winter storm.)

images.title: Yosemite Falls on a Winter Morning
images.altText: Two tall waterfalls flowing down snow covered granite walls.
images.caption: Yosemite Falls will sometimes only trickle at the end of summer, but wet winters can rejuvenate the flow.

images.title: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring
images.altText: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring
images.caption: Upper Yosemite Fall and Merced River in spring

images.title: Rainbow over Half Dome
images.altText: A rainbow over a mountain in the distance.
images.caption: A hike up to Sentinel Dome rewards people with great views of the landscape around them.

images.title: Cathedral Peak and Lake in Autumn
images.altText: A mountain reflecting in a lake.
images.caption: Cathedral Peak is one of the most recognizable peaks in the Yosemite Wilderness.

images.title: Lower Yosemite Fall
images.altText: A waterfall flowing down a granite cliff.
images.caption: The walk to Lower Yosemite Fall is a popular and easy hike.

images.title: View of Yosemite Valley in Winter
images.altText: El Capitan on left, Cathedral Rocks on the right, all covered in snow, low clouds and sun
images.caption: A rewarding view of Yosemite Valley in winter as seen from Tunnel View.

images.title: Yosemite Valley from Tunnel View
images.caption: Tunnel View is perhaps one of the most photographed views in the park.

images.title: Glen Aulin
images.caption: Glen Auilin is one of five High Sierra Camps, located in the Yosemite high country.

images.title: Giant Sequoia Trees in the Mariposa Grove of Giant Sequoias
images.altText: Cluster of tall trees with cloudy sky.
images.caption: Yosemite National Park's massive giant sequoias (Sequoiadendron giganteum) live in three groves in the park. The most famous of these is the Mariposa Grove, which contains about 500 mature giant sequoias.

images.title: Tenaya Lake at Sunset
images.caption: Tenaya Lake is a favorite place to stop along the Tioga Road in summer.
